articles.content:
Tech CEOs say the era of 'code by AI' is here. Some software engineers are skeptical 
         By Huo Jingnan 
        
           Tuesday, October 21, 2025 • 9:17 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         Tech CEOs are making ambitious claims about AI's coding capabilities. In March, Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei  said  "we'll be there in three to six months — where AI is writing 90% of the code." Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg  predicted  in April that for one project "in the next year probably … maybe half the development is going to be done by AI." Executives of  Amazon ,  Google  and  Microsoft  have also highlighted large language models' (LLMs') abilities to generate code. AI tools have changed how coding works for some developers and there are now  fewer  of the most junior software engineers. But despite the dramatic rhetoric, AI in software engineering might not mean a new age of automation. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       After months of sitting on the sidelines, software engineer Colton Voege finally tried out AI tools for his work. He remembered watching a podcast where leaders of tech startup incubator Y Combinator, which helped Voege launch a  company , touted AI's "incredible productivity." "It kind of confirmed what I already felt about it, in that it's really good at shortcutting certain things," Voege said. "[AI] is great for writing little tools that you'll use once and then throw away." But he hasn't seen evidence of long-term boosts to his efficiency. Interviews show that many software engineers, though not all, share Voege's experience. Some tell stories of untangling AI-generated code their colleagues have handed them, others talk about the pressure to make up work that purports to use AI to make higher-ups happy. Yes, AI can write code ... but still needs people In an interview with NPR, Boris Cherny, head of Anthropic's Claude Code unit, said "most code is written by Claude Code," but declined to provide a percentage. "We're still working on the science to make sure we can give a really precise number." Cherny was also clear that no matter how much AI is actually used, "Every line of code should be reviewed by an engineer." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       He said this includes code generated by what Anthropic called "agents." Agents are a component of AI tools that have the ability to test and rewrite code without human intervention. The function, hailed as much more autonomous than previous tools, was first introduced by Claude Code and was celebrated   by many in the industry as a pathway to automation. But agents don't always work. "When these tools are at their best, they'll auto resolve a lot of issues. ... When they're at their worst, they will go into like death spirals," said Voege, describing situations where the tools, far from resolving the issue at hand, get stuck in a testing loop. "I'm like, oh no, you're way off." Cherny did not shy away from describing Claude like a somewhat high functioning person. "I think a good mental model [is that] it's like an expert programmer that's sitting next to you," he said. While he said it can serve as a "thought partner" in some cases, "in the end, it's a human that's doing the work." Simon Willison, an independent AI researcher who was invited to preview OpenAI's latest model, said it's plausible that AI could write a high percentage of code. However, Willison said, "I think they'll still need the same or even more humans involved in that process." That's because AI cannot think through higher-level problem solving like engineers do. "Our job is not to type code into a computer. Our job is to deliver systems that solve problems." Willison said. For Willison, who is known in the software world for tinkering with new tools and developing open-source ones, the productivity bump from using AI depends on choosing appropriate uses and having relevant expertise. "I am comfortable saying that for certain tasks, [for] programmers who are experienced programmers — those who can work without AI — with AI, they can get two to five times [the] productivity boost, sometimes more, depending on the specific task." Willison later wrote in his blog that the teams that benefit the most appear to adopt best practices in software development and collaboration. But that's not always what happens in real life. People are using AI regardless of whether it's needed, which sometimes results in more work for their colleagues. Researchers coined the term " workslop " to describe this. "A very high level engineer at the company was kind of very gung ho about AI coding and thought he could kind of get this very complicated project done very, very quickly on his own and tried running some AI tools," said one engineer at Amazon who is not authorized to speak publicly. "[It] produced this just kind of messy blob of code that didn't work and nobody understood it. And the thing I'm working on now is just trying to actually do it kind of the old way." All this might explain why studies show mixed results when it comes to AI's impact. According to  a study  by AI evaluation nonprofit  METR , experienced open-source software engineers who used LLMs ended up taking 19% longer to complete their tasks compared to peers who did not — contrary to the engineers' own expectations. In a national  survey  in Denmark, software engineers self-reported to have saved 6.5% of their time with AI. It was the highest of the 11 professions, which averaged out to 2.5%. "I'd definitely take 3% any day. It's like annual productivity growth in a typical occupation," said Anders Humlum, co-author of the Denmark study. "It's not nothing, but I would call it modest relative to the experiments." Engineers agree that AI shines more where accuracy matters less. "Knocking out a quick illustrated prototype would take me an hour [before] and now it takes me five minutes because I could just tell Claude to bash something [together]," said Willison. "The fact that it's going to make mistakes and stuff doesn't really matter too much." AI has helped cut back on some repetitive coding tasks at work, said Thomas Ptacek, a software developer at the cloud infrastructure company, fly.io. "Because I've written [a piece of code] many times before … I can also look at that code very quickly and get a sense of whether it's crazy or not." Little room for disagreement The Amazon software engineer said management encouraged staff to use AI in all parts of their work, even when there wasn't a case for using it. "It is very much a solution in search of problems much of the time," the engineer said. The engineer said that all this is fostering a sense that there is little room for disagreement. "You have to use it more and it has to make you more efficient. If you're not, then you're doing something incorrectly." That said, the engineer also said the rhetoric's tangible effects on work and promotion vary across the organization. Amazon isn't the only tech company that appears to make assumptions about AI's effects on code. In a memo  first reported by 404 Media and Wired , a Meta executive called for his department to achieve "5X productivity" in software as well as a broad set of other functions using AI. "The more we push ourselves, the more we'll unlock," he wrote in the memo. Two engineers  were fired  from an AI startup in San Francisco for not using an AI coding tool enough,  The Information  reported. Both the Amazon software engineer and Voege said they aren't the only engineers skeptical of AI in their workplace. A recent Google  survey  of software engineers across different countries and industries showed that while use of AI is near universal and improves aspects of software development, about half of respondents "somewhat" trusted AI's response, and 30% chose "a little" or "not at all." Many are also worried about employers replacing junior coders with AI, effectively cutting off the long-term talent supply that's needed to supervise the machines in the years to come. Others raise concerns about the massive amount of electricity and content made by humans that the largest models consume, even as dramatic capability improvements have begun to seem elusive. In a statement to NPR, Amazon spokesperson Tom Parnell said its in-house AI tools "help engineers move faster, ship more secure code, and spend less time on busywork" and that through surveys "engineers tell us these tools help them save time and feel more productive." He also said that the company does not mandate AI use, and cannot share what percentage of its software engineers regularly use large language model tools, but it believes "these tools can help developers work more efficiently." Voege has since left his job and is now again thinking about starting his own business. He was floored by how much his old funder Y Combinator has gone from supporting different kinds of technologies to focusing solely on AI. He looked at the organization's latest request for startups. "It's just AI, AI, AI, five out of five." 
         
         Correction 
         Oct. 21st, 2025 
         A previous version of this story misstated the name of Anders Humlum as Anders Hulum.

articles.title: Pentagon Implements New Rules on Communications with Congress
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In October 2025, the Pentagon, under Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Deputy Steve Feinberg, introduced a new policy requiring all military officials—including the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff—to obtain prior approval from the Department’s Legislative Affairs Office before engaging with Congress. This move, first reported by Breaking Defense, replaces previous decentralized communication practices with centralized oversight, citing concerns about inconsistent messaging and strategic objectives. The policy includes a working group established on October 17 to refine guidelines on legislative engagement. The change has drawn criticism and resistance, as most Pentagon reporters exited the building in protest of the restrictions, suggesting a significant tension between transparency and control in military communications.
keyTakeAways: Pentagon officials, including the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, are now required to obtain prior approval from the Department’s main legislative affairs office before communicating with Congress.
The new rules were introduced in response to concerns about inconsistent messaging and lack of coordination across military branches.
Most Pentagon reporters exited the building in protest of the new restrictions on their work, indicating strong internal resistance to the policy shift.
The Defense Department’s leadership, under Secretary Pete Hegseth and Deputy Steve Feinberg, is attempting to exert tighter control over how the Pentagon communicates with lawmakers and the public.
A memo explicitly states that unauthorized engagements with Congress may undermine Department-wide priorities critical to achieving legislative objectives.
The move is framed as a 'pragmatic step' to improve communication accuracy and responsiveness, promoting transparency.
The Pentagon previously allowed individual agencies to manage their own communications with Congress, but now centralizes this control under one office.
A working group was established on October 17 to refine the guidance on legislative engagements.

articles.title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a 34-year-old man pardoned by President Donald Trump in early 2025 after participating in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot, has been arrested on a felony charge of making a terroristic threat to House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. According to court documents, Moynihan allegedly texted Jeffries stating, 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.' The arrest, which occurred on or around October 17, 2025, was prompted by FBI intelligence and led to Moynihan being arraigned in Clinton, New York, and held in the Dutchess County Justice and Transition Center. This incident underscores growing concerns about the safety of lawmakers and the broader implications of blanket pardons for individuals with criminal histories, especially those with prior offenses such as domestic violence or sexual abuse. The case reflects a wider pattern of recidivism among pardoned Capitol rioters and raises questions about the long-term public safety impact of executive pardons.
keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter pardoned by President Trump in 2021, was arrested in October 2025 for threatening to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly sent texts in which he stated he would kill Jeffries, saying, 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.'
The arrest occurred after FBI notification that Moynihan had made threats to kill a member of Congress, specifically Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan was arraigned in Clinton, N.Y., and held in the Dutchess County Justice and Transition Center, with bail conditions of $10,000 cash, $30,000 bond, or $80,000 partially secured bond.
He faces a felony charge of making a terroristic threat under federal law.
Moynihan was originally sentenced to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release in 2023 for his role in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.
He received a full pardon along with over 1,500 other individuals charged with Capitol-related crimes under President Trump's blanket pardon in early 2025.
This arrest is part of a growing pattern where former Capitol rioters, especially those with prior criminal records, have committed new violent offenses.
The rise in threats to lawmakers—such as the Capitol Police tracking 14,000 threat assessments by the end of 2025—signals an increasing risk to public officials.
House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries criticized the pardons, stating that many released individuals have committed new crimes and law enforcement is now burdened with protecting communities.

articles.content:
Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries 
         By Barbara Sprunt 
        
           Updated Tuesday, October 21, 2025 • 5:26 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         A man who was pardoned by President Trump after storming the U.S. Capitol in 2021 has been arrested on a charge that he threatened to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. New York State Police  say  Christopher Moynihan was arrested after they were advised by the FBI that he had made "threats to kill a member of Congress." Court documents show his arrest came after he allegedly texted that he planned to kill Jeffries, the top Democrat in the House.   Court records show that on or about October 17, Moynihan allegedly sent texts in which he threatened Jeffries' life, writing "I will kill him for the future." "Hakeem Jeffries makes a speech in a few days in NYC I cannot allow this terrorist to live," one message reads, according to the criminal complaint. "Even if I am hated he must be eliminated," reads another. Moynihan, 34, was arraigned in local court in Clinton, N.Y. He was remanded to the Dutchess County Justice and Transition Center "in lieu of $10,000 cash bail, a $30,000 bond, or an $80,000 partially secured bond." He is scheduled to appear in court on Thursday.  He faces a felony charge of making a terroristic threat. In a  statement  Tuesday, Jeffries noted Moynihan was pardoned on Trump's first day in office. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "Since the blanket pardon that occurred earlier this year, many of the criminals released have committed additional crimes throughout the country," he said. "Unfortunately, our brave men and women in law enforcement are being forced to spend their time keeping our communities safe from these violent individuals who should never have been pardoned." Moynihan  was sentenced  in 2023 to 21 months incarceration, 36 months supervised release. He received a full pardon, along with more than 1,500 other defendants who were charged with crimes related to the storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.  On that day, Moynihan can be heard on a video captured inside the Senate floor saying, "There's got to be something we can use against these f***ing scumbags.''" While many people had no record prior to committing crimes on Jan. 6,  NPR identified dozens of defendants with prior convictions  for crimes including rape, sexual abuse of a minor, domestic violence, manslaughter, production of child sexual abuse material and drug trafficking. That includes Matthew Huttle, who was shot and killed by law enforcement during a traffic stop in Indiana days after receiving a pardon. Moynihan's arrest comes amid rising threats to lawmakers. The Capitol Police told NPR in a statement in September that its agents were on track to work through roughly 14,000 threat assessment cases by the end of the year, a dramatic spike from case workloads in previous years. NPR's Sam Gringlas contributed to this report.

articles.title: Supreme Court Reaffirms Presumption of Innocence and Fair Trial Principles in Criminal Proceedings
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Supreme Court of India delivered a landmark judgment reinforcing fundamental principles of justice in criminal law. The court reaffirmed the presumption of innocence for the accused, emphasizing that no individual can be deemed guilty without a fair and lawful process. It underscored the critical importance of due process, ensuring that all legal procedures are transparent, equitable, and respectful of individual rights. The judgment stressed that only admissible and lawful evidence can be used in court, and that evidence obtained through illegal means is inadmissible. The court reiterated the accused's fundamental rights, including the right to legal representation and the right to remain silent. Furthermore, the decision emphasized that the burden of proof lies entirely with the prosecution, and the standard of proof must be 'beyond reasonable doubt.' This ruling serves as a strong reminder of the judiciary's role in safeguarding justice, protecting individual liberties, and maintaining public trust in the legal system.
keyTakeAways: The court emphasized that the accused must be presumed innocent until proven guilty.
The judgment highlighted the importance of due process and fair trial rights in criminal proceedings.
The ruling underscored that any evidence must be admissible and obtained through lawful means.
The court stressed the necessity of protecting the rights of the accused, including the right to legal representation and to remain silent.
The decision reinforced that the burden of proof lies with the prosecution, and the standard of proof must be beyond reasonable doubt.

articles.title: 5 Things to Know About Sanae Takaichi, Japan's First Female Prime Minister
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Sanae Takaichi, Japan’s first female prime minister, is a conservative leader from Nara Prefecture who rose through the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), gaining support by aligning with right-wing populists after losing its traditional coalition. A devoted admirer of Margaret Thatcher, she embodies a strong, traditional conservative image with a focus on anti-immigration policies, traditional gender roles, and revisionist views on Japan’s wartime history. Though she advocates for women's health and acknowledges her personal experiences with menopause and infertility, she has not prioritized gender equality in her cabinet or policies. Her controversial views on WWII history and the Yasukuni Shrine, combined with her friendship with U.S. President Donald Trump and alignment with hardline foreign policies, signal a shift in Japan’s political direction toward greater nationalism and conservatism. Despite being a historic milestone for gender representation in Japanese politics, Takaichi’s leadership is marked by traditionalism and political controversy.
keyTakeAways: Sanae Takaichi is Japan's first female prime minister, making her a historic figure in a country where women have historically held only about 10% of parliamentary seats.
She is a conservative leader with traditional views on gender roles, opposing same-sex marriage and supporting male-only succession to the Japanese throne.
Takaichi has advocated for stricter immigration policies, including restrictions on non-Japanese property ownership and anti-espionage measures targeting Chinese residents.

She has expressed controversial views on Japan's WWII history, downplaying wartime aggression and criticizing Allied war crimes trials, and has been associated with visits to the Yasukuni Shrine despite recent refraining due to diplomatic sensitivity.

She maintains a strong personal connection to former U.S. President Donald Trump, with mutual social media posts and expectations of a diplomatic visit, reflecting a potential alignment in conservative, anti-immigration, and hawkish foreign policy stances.

articles.content:
5 things to know about Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister 
         By Rachel Treisman 
        
           Tuesday, October 21, 2025 • 12:59 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         Japan's  first-ever female prime minister , Sanae Takaichi, is a conservative with a traditional view of gender roles and a penchant for heavy metal music. Japan's parliament elected Takaichi on Tuesday, several weeks after she was  chosen to lead  the conservative Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), which has spent much of the last seven decades in power. The LDP is seen as shifting further to the right: It was only able to elect Takaichi by forming an alliance with a right-wing populist party, after losing its longtime coalition partner earlier this month. Takaichi, 64, is "one of the most conservative people in Japan's conservative LDP," explains Jeffrey Hall, a lecturer at Kanda University of International Studies in Japan. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       She has advocated for tougher immigration restrictions and embraced hawkish policies on China. She has drawn comparisons to the late British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, for whom she has frequently expressed her admiration and often wears blue suits in tribute. But she also played drums in a band in college, cites Deep Purple and Iron Maiden as some of her favorite bands, once  belted a rock anthem  on national TV and appears to maintain a strong affinity  for motorcycles  and  cars . "Those are part of the character that is promoted by her, that [she is] more than just the strong Iron Lady, but also somebody who can have some fun," Hall says. Here's what else to know about Japan's new leader. 1. She isn't from a political family Takaichi was born and raised in the central Japanese prefecture of Nara. Her dad worked for an automotive firm, while her mom worked for the local police department. "Unlike most or many of the politicians in her party who became prime ministers, she came from rather modest means," Hall says. "But she did study very hard when she was young, and she passed the entrance exams for some very elite private universities in Japan." But he said Takaichi's parents refused to pay for her tuition to an elite university, preferring that she attend a two-year college to save money and live closer to home. She ended up attending Kobe University, a prestigious national university, paying her own way through part-time jobs and making the six-hour round-trip commute from her parents' house. In 1987, Takaichi moved to the U.S. to work as a congressional fellow in the office of  Rep. Pat Schroeder , a Democrat from Colorado — despite her own conservative leanings, Hall notes. After returning to Japan, she was able to market herself as an expert in international politics and secure a job as a television presenter. "And from there, she segued away from being a TV personality into a politician, which is a common path in Japan," Hall says. "If you're famous on TV, you have a pretty good chance of winning elections." 2. She's spent decades in politics  Takaichi was first elected to parliament in 1993, representing her hometown of Nara as an independent. She joined the LDP three years later and went on to serve in a number of key government positions, including minister of economic security. Notably, she served as the minister of international communications — which is responsible for telecommunications policy and broadcast media regulations — under the late Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, from 2014 to 2017 and again from 2019 to 2020. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "She served in that, I think, longer than any other politician has ever served, because the Abe administration was a very long administration and he valued her competency," Hall says. Abe was Japan's longest-serving prime minister, holding office from 2006 to 2007 and 2012 to 2020, before his  assassination in 2022 . He was known for his efforts to revitalize Japan's economy — nicknamed "Abenomics" — and rebuild its role on the global stage. Takaichi "definitely depicts herself as the successor to Abe's conservative legacy," Hall says, noting that she did get his endorsement in the party's 2021 leadership election. "I'm not sure how close friends they were, but they definitely were on the same page ideologically when it came to issues like China and the revisionist view of World War II that many of the ultra-conservatives in Japan have," he said. 3. Her views have caused controversy Takaichi subscribes to modern monetary theory, "which says that you can engage in deficit spending on important things like defense and other parts of the budget," Hall says. While she is not as traditionally fiscally conservative as others in her party, he says, she is extremely conservative on social issues. For instance, she wants to create programs to promote having children and doesn't think women should be allowed to keep their maiden names after marriage (even though she has used hers in professional and public life). 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       She also has what Hall describes as hardline views on Japan's WWII history. In remarks over the years, she has downplayed Japan's aggression during the war and criticized the  war crimes trials  that the Allies held afterward to convict Japan's wartime leaders. Takaichi has been known to regularly visit the controversial Yasukuni Shrine, though she has recently refrained from doing so to avoid political and diplomatic backlash. Yasukuni is a controversial Shinto shrine that honors the spirits of Japan's war dead, including some convicted war criminals from World War II. Takaichi has also courted controversy with her disdain for immigrants and even tourists, a  rapidly growing industry  in Japan. While campaigning, she cited unconfirmed reports of tourists  kicking sacred deer in Nara Park , part of a larger criticism of tourism that many saw as xenophobic. "It also ties into a general dislike of foreign people and also immigrants who live in the country," Hall says. She has advocated for an  anti-espionage law , suggesting that Chinese residents of Japan could be potential spies for China's government. During her campaign, she  called for restrictions  on non-Japanese people buying property in Japan and a crackdown on illegal immigration. "People who are very anti-immigration are sort of smiling on her becoming prime minister, expecting that she will do something about it," Hall says, adding he thinks that is unlikely because of pressure from Japanese businesses who rely on immigration in the face of  significant labor shortages . 4. She's not necessarily a feminist  Takaichi holds a notable place in the history books as the first female prime minister of a country where women only held  about 10% of seats  in parliament as of 2024. Japan, the world's fourth largest economy, ranked 118th out of 148 countries in terms of gender equality — the lowest of any Group of Seven nation — according to the World Economic Forum (WEF)'s 2025  Global Gender Gap Report . However, Takaichi appears unlikely to prioritize issues of gender equality. She has long advocated for traditional gender roles, opposes same-sex marriage and supports male-only succession to the Japanese throne. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "This is not going to be a period when women's equality or other gender issues are aggressively advanced," Hall says. "But there is, I guess, some benefit to having a woman as the leader of your country, to show … young women that in the future they could become prime minister, too." Takaichi has spoken about women's rights, specifically  advocating for the expansion  of hospital services for women's health and opening up about her own  struggles with menopause  symptoms. Takaichi has also spoken about her struggles to conceive; She has no biological children, but is a stepmother to three kids — and grandmother to four — from her husband's previous marriage. (She is married to former member of parliament and fellow LDP member  Taku Yamamoto , who legally took her last name, a relative rarity in Japan.) Takaichi had promised on the campaign trail to increase the number of women in her cabinet to " Nordic levels ," or  closer to 50% . But in the hours after taking office, she  appointed only two . Hall says Takaichi has had to be more conservative than her male colleagues in order to take the helm of the party. While she and her role model Margaret Thatcher differ in their approaches to fiscal policy, he says both are conservative, hawkish and "do not want to be seen as weak." "She maybe, in a way, has modeled her rise on Margaret Thatcher by being this very strong figure, despite coming [up] in a party of very conservative men who generally do not promote women to the highest positions," he adds. 5. She appears friendly toward Trump Takaichi has indicated a friendliness toward President Trump, who called her "a highly respected person of great wisdom and strength" in a  social media post  earlier this month congratulating her on her rise to party leadership and her expected ascension to prime minister. She responded with a post of her own, writing in both English and Japanese that she is "truly hoping to work together with President Trump to make our alliance even stronger & more prosperous, and to advance a Free and Open Indo-Pacific." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Hall says Trump likely has a good first impression of Takaichi already, because of her reputation as an "anti-immigration, hard-line conservative who is a respecter of his late friend Shinzo Abe." Abe was one of the first foreign leaders to cultivate a relationship with Trump during his first term. The  two became friends  as they bonded over wagyu beef burgers, sumo wrestling and golf. Trump is expected to meet Takaichi on a visit to Japan later this month. Hall predicts she will follow the same playbook as her predecessors: "You be as nice as possible to the president, you show him the maximum respect, you do not have public disagreements with him," he says. "And when you do disagree over policy, you do it in a very subtle way that doesn't seem like you're telling the president he's wrong." 
         
         CORRECTION 
         Oct. 22nd, 2025 
         A previous version of this story mischaracterized the Yasukuni Shrine.

articles.title: Trump’s Beef Import Plan Faces Rancher and Expert Pushback
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump's proposal to lower U.S. beef prices by increasing imports from Argentina is facing strong opposition from American ranchers and agricultural experts. Despite Argentina currently accounting for only 2% of U.S. beef imports, economists argue that such a move would not significantly reduce grocery store prices. Ranchers are concerned that the policy introduces economic uncertainty, undermining investment in domestic cattle production, especially during profitable years. Experts like Glynn Tonsor caution that Argentina may face domestic price increases if it exports too much beef. While Argentine producers welcome new buyers, U.S. ranchers fear the policy contradicts the administration's stated goal of boosting domestic production. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and Senator John Hoeven support efforts to help ranchers, and there is hope Trump will reconsider the plan. The article highlights a clash between political rhetoric and economic realities in U.S. agriculture.
keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump's proposal to import more beef from Argentina to lower prices is facing strong opposition from U.S. ranchers.
Argentine beef currently accounts for only about 2% of U.S. beef imports, and experts argue that increasing imports would not significantly reduce beef prices at grocery stores.
Ranchers are concerned that increased importation undermines their current profitability and creates economic uncertainty, reducing investment in cattle production.
The U.S. beef market is experiencing high prices due to strong demand and a historically small herd size since 1961, exacerbated by drought and low cattle prices in previous years.
Tariffs on Brazil and trade restrictions with Mexico have reduced overall beef imports, contributing to current price levels.
Kansas State University economist Glynn Tonsor and other experts caution that Argentina may face higher domestic prices if it exports too much beef to the U.S.
Ranchers such as Brett Kenzy, Bryant Kagay, and Bill Bullard express skepticism and concern, arguing that the policy contradicts Trump’s stated goal of boosting domestic production.
Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins and Senator John Hoeven support efforts to help ranchers while reducing consumer prices, suggesting future policy adjustments.
The proposal creates uncertainty, which may discourage ranchers from expanding herds despite recent profitable years.
Most imported Argentine beef is lean trimmings used in ground beef production, so changes would primarily affect hamburger prices, not steak.

articles.title: Israel Takes Steps to Shut Down International Aid Groups in Gaza and the West Bank
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Israel has implemented sweeping measures to restrict international humanitarian aid in Gaza and the West Bank, banning the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA) from sending aid and personnel, and initiating a new re-registration process for international non-governmental organizations (INGOs). The new criteria, enforced by COGAT and involving committees that include Israel’s Ministry for Diaspora Affairs, target organizations accused of supporting terrorist activities or inciting racism—often based on broad, politically charged definitions of antisemitism. Major aid groups like the Norwegian Refugee Council and Mercy Corps are in limbo, with some already de-registered or denied access. Despite a U.S.-brokered ceasefire promising increased aid, Israel continues to block crossings, with only two of seven border crossings open and hundreds of aid trucks stranded in Egypt and Jordan. UNRWA, which had been the largest provider of aid in Gaza, now faces a severe funding shortfall due to U.S. withdrawal of support, while its warehouses hold enough supplies to feed Gaza for three months. Humanitarian officials argue that the restrictions are not for security but are ideologically motivated and threaten to dismantle decades of humanitarian infrastructure in Palestine.
keyTakeAways: Israel has banned the UNRWA agency from sending aid to Gaza, citing unsubstantiated claims that it employs Hamas members.

Israel has initiated a new process to de-register major international nongovernmental aid organizations (INGOs) based on ideological grounds, such as accusations of supporting terrorist activities or inciting racism.

The re-registration process for INGOs requires approval from a committee including Israel’s Ministry for Diaspora Affairs and Combating Antisemitism, raising concerns about political bias and lack of transparency.
Many major aid groups, including the Norwegian Refugee Council and Mercy Corps, are in limbo or have been denied re-registration, effectively halting their operations in Gaza and the West Bank.
Humanitarian officials report that over 300 aid trucks have been waiting in Egypt and Jordan for months, with only two of seven border crossings open to aid traffic.
Israel claims aid restrictions are for security, but aid groups argue the process is designed to delegitimize organizations through broad definitions of antisemitism and terrorism.
The U.S. stopped funding UNRWA in 2024, creating a financial crisis that has left UNRWA struggling to meet basic humanitarian needs in Gaza.
UNRWA's warehouses in Jordan and Egypt hold enough supplies to feed the entire Gaza population for three months, but Israel continues to block deliveries despite this.
Aid organizations claim the new regulations are politically motivated and threaten to dismantle decades of humanitarian aid infrastructure in Palestine.

articles.content:
Israel takes steps to shut down international aid groups in Gaza and the West Bank 
         By Jane Arraf 
        
           Tuesday, October 21, 2025 • 1:30 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         AMMAN, Jordan — Israel, having banned the United Nations aid agency for Palestinian refugees from sending aid and staff to Gaza, is now taking unprecedented steps to de-register major nongovernmental aid groups for ideological reasons, according to several officials of   humanitarian organizations. They say the new rules threaten the ability of some of the biggest international nongovernmental organizations — known as INGOs — to send in aid or staff to both Gaza and the Israeli-occupied West Bank. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "INGOs are in limbo — most who have submitted have either been not accepted or rejected," an official with an aid organization that is aware of the situation said of the application process required for nongovernmental aid organizations operating in Gaza and the West Bank. The official spoke on the condition that NPR not name their employer and not give their name because they are not authorized to speak publicly. The ceasefire agreement in the Gaza war brokered this month by President Trump committed Israel to a surge in aid into Gaza, where food security experts  declared famine  in parts of the territory. But Israel continues to severely restrict crossings open for aid shipments and who can send aid through them. Of seven Israeli border crossings with Gaza, only two are currently open. Of those that are open, the U.N. and nongovernmental aid groups say many requests to enter Gaza are routinely rejected, without explanation. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The Israeli military has claimed, without providing evidence, that its aid restrictions are needed for security. Israel this fall began requiring that all international aid groups re-register  under new criteria , including approval by a committee which includes representatives from Israel's Ministry for Diaspora Affairs and Combating Antisemitism. Reasons for delisting aid groups include supporting "terrorist groups and activities in accordance with Israel law" and "inciting racism," according to COGAT, the Israeli military's arm that is part of NGO approval process. Aid organizations say the reasoning appears to be used to refer to a wide variety of comments the Israeli government classifies as antisemitic. Israel has in the past accused some aid groups and medical providers of being terrorist organizations. Israel had also demanded that organizations provide personnel details for all local and international staff, a measure rejected by most major aid groups as potentially putting staff in danger. The Norwegian Refugee Council, registered in Gaza since 2009, is one of the major aid groups unable to send in supplies or staff while its application is being considered. "We quickly realized that the intent behind the process wasn't to facilitate the re-registration of humanitarian INGOs but rather to find a way to re-register us and to remove our ability to operate," says Ivan Karakashian, communications manager for the NRC in Jerusalem. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       He says there were no clear guidelines as to what delegitimizing Israel included. Any de-registered organizations would have to cease operations in both Gaza and the Israeli occupied West Bank within 60 days, according to aid officials familiar with the criteria. The Israeli military arm responsible for borders and coordination with INGO operations did not respond to NPR's requests for comment on reasons for de-registering or delaying registration of some organizations. Many of those aid groups waiting to be re-registered have had hundreds of trucks waiting for months in Egypt and Jordan intended for Gaza. Humanitarian officials said at least one major U.S.-based NGO has already been de-registered and is now in the appeal process. The organization in question declined to discuss the issue with NPR. Another U.S.-based aid group, Mercy Corps, said following the ceasefire agreement, it had submitted a request to send in aid but it was denied by Israeli authorities because the organization was in the process of re-registering. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Humanitarian officials said Israel has approved a dozen NGOs that do not coordinate within traditional U.N.-led structures and are either ideologically driven or have little experience in humanitarian aid or both. They include one U.S. aid group that partnered with the controversial Gaza Humanitarian Foundation — a militarized aid response in which almost all other aid groups refused to participate. COGAT did not respond to a request for comment on new aid organizations given registration. At the same time, Israel continues to ban the U.N. agency for providing aid to Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA, from sending in aid or staff to Gaza. Israel accused UNRWA, without evidence, of employing hundreds of Hamas members, including some involved in the Oct. 7, 2023, attack in Israel. It has sought since the start of the Gaza war to replace the U.N. aid system that has provided humanitarian assistance there for decades. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       UNRWA, with 12,000 local staff, was the biggest humanitarian organization in Gaza, running shelters, mobile medical clinics, water and sanitation projects and schools. "The warehouses in Jordan and Egypt are full of food that can feed the entire population of Gaza for three months and we need to bring that in," says Tamara Alrifai, UNRWA's director of external relations. The supplies also include medicine, tents, blankets and hygiene products. Israeli airstrikes have damaged or destroyed  more than 90% of homes  in Gaza and most of the civilian infrastructure, according to U.N. figures. The United States, which had been UNRWA's biggest donor, stopped its funding last year, which Alrifai says led to a loss of about one-quarter of UNRWA's total income. Alrifai says while European and other countries have increased their contributions, it does not fill the funding gap. The European Union's top humanitarian aid official said after the Israeli accusations against UNRWA  he saw no evidence from Israel  backing them. Alrifai says UNRWA was trying to start discussions with the U.S. through other countries about renewing the funding. "We have not had direct talks but we have passed on messages through other governments who are close to Gaza and close to the U.S." she says. Aya Batrawy contributed reporting from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. 
         
         Transcript 
         SCOTT SIMON, HOST:   Israeli strikes in Gaza continue despite its military pulling back troops under a U.S.-brokered ceasefire that took effect last week. Today, an attack killed a Palestinian family of 11, including seven children and three women. Israel also committed under the ceasefire to dramatically increase the amount of aid it allows in. Aid groups say that isn't happening. NPR's Jane Arraf joins us now. Jane, thanks for being with us. JANE ARRAF, BYLINE: Thank you, Scott. SIMON: What's happened in this attack, and what's happening with the ceasefire? ARRAF: Well, Gaza Civil Defense authorities say this was one of the many families returning to inspect the ruins of their home in Gaza City when Israeli forces fired a tank round at their minibus. The Israeli military said that the family was behind the yellow line where its troops are positioned and that they fired on it because they were an imminent threat. That yellow line, Scott, is visible on the map, we have to note, but not so much to families on the ground. And the ceasefire itself, it's still holding overall, but Israel still controls more than 50% of Gaza territory. It says it plans to mark that yellow line with a physical barrier. SIMON: Israel also pledged to allow 600 aid trucks per day into Gaza. Has that happened? ARRAF: It hasn't. The U.N. says that 600 is the bare minimum to keep people from starving, to provide shelter and repair infrastructure in what is a totally devastated territory. Israel is still keeping shut one of those main border crossings, Rafah, which is Egypt's border crossing with Gaza. And that's where many hundreds of trucks have been waiting for months to be allowed in. It has been allowing aid through two other crossings. But there, it's a bit of a numbers game because Israel refers to all trucks as aid trucks. So just to give you an example, two days ago, the figures show 950 trucks entered Gaza. But a Trump administration official shed some light on that. It appears that only about 10% of that figure were U.N. or international aid organizations, and most of the rest were commercial imports. Those are imports from Israel, by the way. SIMON: And the United Nations has urged Israel to allow the aid organization with which it partners to continue to send aid into Gaza. Help us understand that. ARRAF: Yeah. That's a huge issue which hasn't received a lot of attention. The U.N. doesn't need to be registered, but international nongovernmental organizations, INGOs, do. And Israel this year said it would shut down aid groups that didn't reregister under the new criteria, so it's begun that process. This criteria has a committee that determines whether the organizations have delegitimized Israel through statements or anything else. Here's Ivan Karakashian, the communications manager at the Norwegian Refugee Council in Jerusalem. IVAN KARAKASHIAN: We quickly realized that this wasn't - the intent behind the process wasn't to facilitate the reregistration of INGOs, of humanitarian INGOs, but rather to find a way to deregister us - right? - and to remove our ability to operate within the occupied Palestinian territory. ARRAF: He says his organization is in the process of trying to reregister, and that also applies to some of the biggest U.S. aid groups. If they don't, if they can't, that means they're shut down. SIMON: Jane, the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees, known as UNRWA, was the biggest provider of aid in Gaza for decades before Israel banned staff and shipments there. Is that expected to change? ARRAF: Israel hasn't given any indication it's lifting that ban. It had claimed - without evidence - that hundreds of UNRWA staff are Hamas. And the U.S. also cut funding to UNRWA. Some of that funding, but not all of it, was made up by other countries. I spoke with UNRWA's head of external relations, Tamara Alrifai, and here's what she had to say. TAMARA ALRIFAI: We still are trying to work our way back into discussions with the U.S. You know how they say it takes a village? It takes an international community to want the situation in Gaza, in the occupied Palestinian territory and in the region to be stable. ARRAF: UNRWA has been banned by Israel from sending in supplies since March. It has warehouses in Egypt and here in Jordan full of food that UNRWA says could feed the entire population of Gaza for three months. SIMON: NPR's Jane Arraf. Thanks so much. ARRAF: Thank you.

articles.title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates in U.S. Children
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the LEAP trial showed that introducing peanuts to infants early in life reduces the risk of developing food allergies, new research confirms that this practice has made a significant real-world impact, with a 27% to 40% drop in peanut allergy rates among young children in the U.S. since 2015. The findings, based on analysis of electronic health records, indicate that about 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since the 2015 guidelines were issued. Despite initial resistance from clinicians and parents, adoption of early allergen introduction—such as through small amounts of peanut butter or soy-based yogurt—has increased, supported by updated medical guidelines from 2021. Experts like Dr. David Hill and organizations like FARE emphasize that early exposure is both safe and effective, reinforcing its role in reducing the prevalence of a major public health concern.
keyTakeAways: The introduction of peanut products to infants as early as 4 months has led to a more than 27% reduction in peanut allergies in children aged 0 to 3, and over 40% reduction after expanded guidelines in 2017.
Approximately 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015, with the practice showing long-term protective effects in about 70% of children into adolescence.
The LEAP trial, led by Gideon Lack at King’s College London, demonstrated that early exposure to peanuts reduces the risk of developing food allergies by over 80%.

Despite initial hesitation among medical professionals and parents, adoption of early allergen introduction has increased, with current guidance emphasizing safe and simple exposures like peanut butter or soy-based yogurt.

The new research confirms that real-world implementation of these guidelines has made measurable public health impacts, reinforcing the importance of evidence-based recommendations in pediatric nutrition.

articles.title: Books about race and gender to be returned to school libraries on some military bases
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal judge ruled that the Department of Defense Education Activity (DoDEA) violated the First Amendment by removing nearly 600 books on race, gender, and LGBTQ+ issues from schools on military bases in Virginia, Kentucky, Italy, and Japan. These removals were carried out under directives from President Trump’s executive orders and Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth’s memoranda, which banned instruction on Critical Race Theory, DEI, and gender ideology, and prohibited celebrations like Black and Women’s History Months. Students, children of active-duty service members, claimed their rights were violated, reporting that they were punished for protesting, and that classrooms became fearful of discussing race and gender. Judge Patricia Tolliver Giles found the removals to be politically motivated rather than pedagogical, and ordered the immediate return of all removed books and curricula.
keyTakeAways: Federal Judge Patricia Tolliver Giles ruled that the removal of books on race and gender from military school libraries was not pedagogically justified but driven by improper partisan motives.

The Department of Defense Education Activity (DoDEA) removed nearly 600 books from schools on military bases in Virginia, Kentucky, Italy, and Japan, citing executive orders against gender ideology and critical race theory.
Students from pre-K to 11th grade, children of active-duty service members, claimed their First Amendment rights were violated, and were punished for protesting the removals.
The ACLU of Virginia, the ACLU of Kentucky, and the ACLU of Virginia filed a motion requesting the return of all removed books and curricula, citing violations of constitutional rights.
Schools canceled events such as Black History Month, Holocaust Remembrance Day, and removed educational materials like posters of Malala Yousafzai and Frida Kahlo.
The judge ruled that the removals were politically motivated and ordered the immediate return of all quarantined books and curricular materials.

articles.content:
Books about race and gender to be returned to school libraries on some military bases 
         By Elizabeth Blair 
        
           Tuesday, October 21, 2025 • 12:26 PM EDT 
        
        
      

         A federal judge ordered the Department of Defense Monday to return books about gender and race back to five school libraries on military bases. In April, 12 students at schools on military bases in Virginia, Kentucky, Italy and Japan claimed their First Amendment rights had been violated when nearly 600 books were removed from the Department of Defense Education Activity (DoDEA) schools they attend. The students are the children of active duty service members ranging from pre-K to 11th grade. The American Civil Liberties Union, the ACLU of Kentucky, and the ACLU of Virginia filed a motion on behalf of the families requesting the return of "all books and curriculum already quarantined or removed based on potential violation of the Executive Orders." Earlier this year, President Trump issued executive orders  demanding  federal agencies remove and prohibit any materials that promote "gender ideology and discriminatory equity ideology." In January, Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth issued the memoranda " Restoring America's Fighting Force ," which prohibited "instruction on Critical Race Theory (CRT), DEI, or gender ideology," and " Identity Months Dead at DoD ," which barred using official resources for celebrations such as Black History Month, Women's History Month and Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month. According to the plaintiffs, DoDEA officials sent emails directing teachers to remove books and cancel lesson plans and events that would be in violation of Trump's executive orders and Hegseth's guidance. Books removed from school libraries at military bases covered such topics as sexual identity, racism and LGBTQ pride. You can see a list of the books  here . Two elementary schools cancelled Black History Month events, teachers at a middle school were told to remove posters of education activist Malala Yousafzai and painter Frida Kahlo and another school cancelled Holocaust Remembrance Day. According to the motion filed by the ACLU, the students claimed that when they protested the school's actions, they were punished and became "increasingly afraid to discuss race and gender in their classrooms, because they fear being silenced by teachers fearful of violating the EOs and DoDEA guidance." In her  decision , U.S. District Court Judge Patricia Tolliver Giles sided with the students and their families, writing that "the removals were not rooted in pedagogical concerns" but rather there was "improper partisan motivation underlying [defendants'] actions." Giles wrote that DOD officials must "immediately restore the books and curricular materials that have been removed." The Department of Defense and the Department of Defense Education Activity (DoDEA) have not yet responded to NPR's request for comment.

articles.title: U.S. Department of Justice Reviews Request for Election Monitors in New Jersey’s Passaic County
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Department of Justice is reviewing a request from the New Jersey Republican State Committee to deploy federal election monitors to oversee mail ballot processing in Passaic County, a historically Democratic area that flipped to support Donald Trump in 2024. Republicans allege a long history of vote fraud and claim state officials have failed to act, citing a 2020 case where 800 ballots were rejected in Paterson due to suspicious mail-in ballots. The state government, led by Attorney General Matt Platkin, rejects federal involvement, arguing that elections are a state responsibility under the U.S. Constitution. This dispute reflects broader national debates over mail-in voting, election integrity, and the appropriate role of federal versus state authorities in state elections.
keyTakeAways: The U.S. Department of Justice is reviewing a request from New Jersey Republicans to send federal election monitors to oversee mail ballot handling in Passaic County.
Passaic County, a long-time Democratic stronghold, shifted to support Donald Trump in 2024, making it a critical battleground in the November 2025 gubernatorial race.
New Jersey Republicans allege a history of voter fraud in the county and claim state officials have failed to act, calling for federal intervention to ensure transparency in vote counting.

New Jersey state officials, including Attorney General Matt Platkin, argue that federal oversight is inappropriate and that state authorities are responsible for managing elections under the U.S. Constitution.

The 2020 Paterson city council race in Passaic County involved a judge-ordered new election after allegations of voter fraud, with 800 ballots rejected due to suspicious mail-in ballots found in mailboxes.
Donald Trump has long questioned mail-in voting, claiming it is riddled with fraud, despite evidence showing no widespread fraud in U.S. elections.
Trump previously pledged to ban vote-by-mail nationwide, but lacks constitutional authority to do so.
The controversy reflects broader national debates over election integrity, mail voting, and the role of federal versus state governments in overseeing elections.

articles.title: North Korea Conducts First Ballistic Missile Test in Five Months Ahead of U.S. Diplomatic Summit
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: North Korea conducted its first ballistic missile test in five months, launching multiple short-range missiles from an area south of Pyongyang that flew about 350 kilometers toward the northeast. The test, occurring just before a major U.S. diplomatic visit to Asia and during the upcoming APEC summit, is seen as a strategic provocation to assert its nuclear status and pressure the U.N. to lift sanctions. The South Korean military detected the launch and confirmed the missiles did not land in the sea, emphasizing readiness to defend against provocations. Japan’s new Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi is sharing real-time missile warning data with U.S. and South Korean allies to strengthen regional defense coordination. Experts note that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has been accelerating weapons development since failed diplomatic talks with the U.S. in 2019, and the recent display of the Hwasong-20 intercontinental ballistic missile—described as a 'most powerful nuclear strategic weapon system' capable of carrying multiple warheads—suggests a deliberate effort to gain international recognition as a nuclear state. This development has heightened tensions in the region, particularly as Trump is set to visit South Korea for a series of high-level meetings, including with South Korean and Chinese leaders.
keyTakeAways: North Korea conducted its first ballistic missile test in five months, signaling heightened military activity ahead of major international diplomacy.
The missile test occurred from an area south of Pyongyang, with flight path reaching 350 kilometers toward the northeast, and no sea impact reported.
South Korea's military remains on high alert, emphasizing readiness to repel provocations under its alliance with the United States.
Japan's new Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi is sharing real-time missile warning data with U.S. and South Korean authorities to enhance regional defense coordination.
Experts believe North Korea may test missiles before or during the APEC summit to gain recognition as a nuclear weapons state and to pressure the U.N. to lift sanctions.

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has been accelerating weapons development since diplomatic efforts with the U.S. in 2019 failed, and recent displays of new ICBMs suggest a strategic push for global recognition.

The Hwasong-20 intercontinental ballistic missile, showcased in a military parade, is described by North Korea as its 'most powerful nuclear strategic weapon system' and is believed to carry multiple warheads capable of evading U.S. missile defenses.

articles.title: OpenAI Launches Atlas Browser, Challenging Google’s Chrome in AI-Driven Web Search
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: OpenAI launched its Atlas browser on October 21, 2025, introducing an AI-driven interface that replaces the traditional URL bar with a chatbot that autonomously searches the internet on behalf of users. The launch marks a direct challenge to Google’s Chrome browser, which has over 3 billion users and already integrates AI features from Google’s Gemini technology. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman envisions a future where AI agents, powered by user browsing history, conduct searches and explain their actions, raising concerns about user privacy, autonomy, and the potential for biased or ad-influenced recommendations. Analyst Paddy Harrington of Forrester warns that such personalization could remove individual agency from online experiences. Meanwhile, studies show that nearly half of AI-generated responses to news questions are flawed, raising questions about reliability and journalistic standards. With 60% of Americans and 74% of those under 30 using AI tools to find information, the shift toward AI-driven browsing is accelerating, prompting legal and ethical debates over content ownership, copyright, and the future of online content consumption.
keyTakeAways: OpenAI launched its Atlas browser on October 21, 2025, directly challenging Google's Chrome and introducing AI-powered search features.
The browser features an 'agent mode' that autonomously searches the internet using user history and intent, raising concerns about user privacy and agency.
OpenAI's move aims to capture internet traffic and advertising revenue, but faces a formidable market challenge from Chrome, which holds ~3 billion users and has AI features from Google's Gemini.
Analyst Paddy Harrington warns that AI browsers may 'take personality away from users' by using personal data to generate tailored, potentially biased or ad-influenced responses.
About 60% of Americans, and 74% of those under 30, use AI tools to find information, indicating growing reliance on AI for search and content discovery.
AI tools like ChatGPT and Google's Gemini have shown significant flaws in journalism-related responses, with nearly half failing quality standards according to a European Broadcasting Union study.
Concerns persist over AI-generated content hallucinations, copyright infringement, and the impact on traditional online publishers who rely on traffic and clicks.

More than 420 anti-science bills attacking longstanding public health protections –  vaccines , milk safety and  fluoride  – have been introduced in statehouses across the U.S. this year, part of  an organized, politically savvy campaign  to enshrine a conspiracy theory-driven agenda into law. An  Associated Press investigation  found that the  wave of legislation  has cropped up in most states, pushed by people with close ties to Health and Human Services Secretary  Robert F. Kennedy Jr.  The effort would strip away protections that have been built over a century and are integral to American lives and society. Around 30 bills have been enacted or adopted in 12 states. 
    
     Also from AP’s investigation into the wave of anti-science bills in statehouses across the US: Powerful anti-vaccine advocates and people selling potentially harmful goods are  profiting from the push to write anti-science policies into law . They portray the MAHA movement as grassroots, but it’s fueled by a web of well-funded national groups led by people who’ve profited from sowing distrust of medicine and science. How AP tracked and analyzed the legislation , with a focus on bills related to vaccines, fluoride and raw, unpasteurized milk 
    
 
 Trump administration officials are directing activists to push anti-science legislation in the states – where public health authority rests – with the ultimate goal of changing laws and minds nationally. The effort normalizes ideas fueled by the anti-vaccine movement that  Kennedy has helped lead  for years. His  Make America Healthy Again  agenda masks anti-science ideas while promoting goals such as  making food more natural  or reducing chemicals. Meanwhile, vaccination rates  continue to fall , allowing the infectious diseases  measles  and  whooping cough  to make comebacks as Kennedy has sought to broadly remake federal policies on public health matters including fluoride and  vaccines .

articles.title: North Atlantic Right Whale Population Shows Encouraging Growth Amid Conservation Efforts
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The North Atlantic right whale population has shown a positive recovery trend, increasing to an estimated 384 animals in 2025, up from 376 in 2024. This marks a 7% growth over four years after a 25% decline from 2010 to 2020. Scientists from the New England Aquarium’s Cabot Center and NOAA attribute the improvement to new conservation efforts, especially in Canada's Gulf of St. Lawrence. Despite progress, threats such as ship collisions, fishing gear entanglement, and low reproduction rates persist. This year, four mother whales gave birth, and some showed shorter reproductive intervals, signaling improved health. However, only 11 calves were born, which is below expectations. Environmental groups like Oceana warn that the species remains on the brink of extinction and call for stronger legal protections, including support for the Marine Mammal Protection Act, to ensure long-term survival.
keyTakeAways: The North Atlantic right whale population has increased to an estimated 384 individuals, up from the previous year.
A 7% increase in the population over the past four years suggests a positive recovery trend after a 25% decline from 2010 to 2020.
The population growth is attributed to conservation measures, including new management in Canada and improved protections against ship collisions and fishing gear entanglements.
Despite progress, the species remains vulnerable due to ongoing threats such as injuries, malnutrition, and low reproduction rates.
This year, four mother whales had calves for the first time, and some established mothers showed shorter intervals between births — a significant sign of improved reproductive health.
Only 11 calves were born this year, which is below researchers' hopes, but the addition of new females into the reproductive pool is encouraging.

Environmental groups warn that the species is still on the brink of extinction and call for stronger legal protections, including support for the Marine Mammal Protection Act and NOAA’s science-based safeguards.
The whales' migration patterns have been affected by ocean warming, forcing them to travel into less protected areas in search of food, increasing their risk of mortality.

articles.title: Jack Nicklaus Wins $50 Million Defamation Verdict Against Former Business Partners
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Jack Nicklaus, the legendary 18-time major golf champion, has won a $50 million defamation verdict in a Florida lawsuit filed against his former business partners, the Nicklaus Companies, over false claims that he was involved in a $750 million deal with LIV Golf and suffering from dementia. A six-person jury in Palm Beach County found that these allegations damaged Nicklaus’ reputation and exposed him to ridicule, hatred, and distrust. While Howard Milstein and Andrew O’Brien were named as individual defendants, the jury concluded they were not personally liable. The defense had argued the case was merely a business dispute with no reputational harm, but the jury rejected that narrative. This verdict follows a prior legal battle in New York where Nicklaus Companies unsuccessfully tried to prevent him from using his name and likeness for independent golf course design. Though Nicklaus is now free to use his name independently, the company retains rights to use 'Jack Nicklaus' on merchandise.
keyTakeAways: Jack Nicklaus, an 18-time major golf champion, won a $50 million defamation verdict against his former business partners in a Florida lawsuit.

The jury found that the Nicklaus Companies, led by Howard Milstein and Andrew O’Brien, damaged Nicklaus’ reputation by spreading false claims about a $750 million deal with LIV Golf and allegations of dementia.
Howard Milstein and Andrew O’Brien were named as individual defendants, but the jury did not find them personally liable.
The lawsuit stemmed from claims that Nicklaus was mentally unfit and involved in a deal with Saudi-backed LIV Golf, which Nicklaus denied.
Defense attorneys argued the case was a business dispute and not defamation, claiming no actual harm to Nicklaus’ reputation.
Prior to this case, a New York judge dismissed a lawsuit by the Nicklaus Companies seeking to restrict Nicklaus’ use of his name and likeness.

Nicklaus joined the company in 2007 under a $145 million deal and later left to pursue independent golf course design, though the company retains rights to use the 'Jack Nicklaus' name on products like clothing and equipment.

articles.title: Man Pardoned After Storming Capitol Is Charged with Threating to Kill Hakeem Jeffries
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher P. Moynihan, a 34-year-old man previously convicted of participating in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot, was pardoned by President Donald Trump in January 2021. In October 2025, he was arrested on a felony charge of making a terroristic threat against U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, after sending a text message stating he would kill Jeffries during a speech in New York City. The threat, which included explicit statements such as 'I will kill him for the future' and 'must be eliminated,' was reported by an FBI task force and led to swift law enforcement action. The case is currently under review by Dutchess County District Attorney Anthony Parisi for legal and factual sufficiency. The incident draws national attention to the dangers of political extremism, the consequences of executive pardons, and the need for robust protections for elected officials.
keyTakeAways: Christopher P. Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter, was pardoned by President Donald Trump in January 2021 after being convicted of obstructing a joint session of Congress on January 6, 2021.

Moynihan is now charged with making a terroristic threat against U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, after sending a text message stating he would kill Jeffries during a speech in New York City.
The threat was reported by an FBI task force and led to Moynihan's arrest in New York State, with law enforcement and Democratic leaders condemning the act as violent and unacceptable.
The incident underscores the ongoing tension between political extremism, executive pardons, and the protection of elected officials.
Dutchess County District Attorney Anthony Parisi stated the case is under review for legal and factual sufficiency, reflecting the seriousness of the threat to public officials.

articles.title: Wisconsin Man Charged with Stalking After Sending Threatening Emails to Supreme Court Justice Jill Karofsky
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A Wisconsin man, Ryan Thornton, has been charged with stalking after sending nine threatening emails to liberal Supreme Court Justice Jill Karofsky between August and October 2025. The emails included insults, requests for her home address, and paranoid references to helicopter surveillance. Karofsky, who has faced threats since becoming a judge in 2017, reported the messages made her afraid to leave her home and requested police escort to sports events. Thornton also made over 70 calls to the Office of Lawyer Regulation, complaining about a 2019 legal case, indicating possible underlying grievances. If convicted, he faces up to 3.5 years in prison. The case raises concerns about the safety of public officials and the intersection of personal hostility, legal frustration, and online harassment.
keyTakeAways: Ryan Thornton, a 37-year-old man from Racine, Wisconsin, was charged with one felony count of stalking after sending nine threatening emails to Justice Jill Karofsky between August and October 2025.

The emails included insults such as calling Karofsky 'manipulative' and instructing her to 'eject' herself from office, as well as a request for her home address and a comment about helicopter videos suggesting surveillance.

Thornton made profane remarks, stating Karofsky was 'going down' and claiming she 'better start running or something for the hills of the feds because it’s a conspiracy,' indicating extremist or paranoid beliefs.
Karofsky has received numerous threats since 2017, and Thornton’s messages caused her to feel afraid enough to avoid leaving her home and request police escort to sports events.

Thornton made over 70 calls to the Office of Lawyer Regulation between August 1 and October 1, 2025, complaining about a lawyer he hired in a 2019 case, suggesting a pattern of legal grievances and possible obsession.
If convicted, Thornton faces up to 3.5 years in prison.
Public defender Britney Dickey declined to comment on the case.

articles.title: Japan Elected First Female Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, Amid Political and Geopolitical Tensions
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Sanae Takaichi has been elected as Japan’s first female prime minister following the Liberal Democratic Party’s electoral defeats and loss of parliamentary majority. Her rise marks a historic shift in Japanese politics, signaling a potential shift toward stronger national defense and closer alignment with U.S. policy in the Indo-Pacific. Takaichi, a known security hawk and protege of Shinzo Abe, leads a fragile coalition with the Japan Innovation Party, which lacks a majority and faces challenges in passing legislation. While her election is celebrated as a milestone in gender representation, it is also criticized for her opposition to gender equality and LGBTQ+ rights, including support for male-only succession and opposition to same-sex marriage. Takaichi’s policies and diplomatic engagements—especially with U.S. President Donald Trump and South Korean President Lee Jae-myung—are central to Japan’s geopolitical strategy amid tensions with China over history and Taiwan. Meanwhile, the European Union expresses support, emphasizing the importance of Japan’s role in global stability and economic cooperation. The political fragility of her government and her nationalist views raise concerns about long-term stability and regional peace.
keyTakeAways: Sanae Takaichi is Japan’s first female prime minister, a historic milestone in a traditionally male-dominated political landscape.

Her election follows the Liberal Democratic Party’s (LDP) significant electoral losses in July and the loss of its parliamentary majority, indicating political instability and a shift in Japanese public sentiment.
Takaichi is a staunch national conservative and security hawk, emphasizing Japan’s alliance with the United States and its strategic role in countering China’s influence in the Indo-Pacific.
Her governing coalition with the Japan Innovation Party (Ishin no Kai) lacks a majority in both houses, making the government politically fragile and reliant on cooperation with opposition parties.

Takaichi has not advanced gender equality policies, opposing women’s rights such as same-sex marriage, separate surnames for married couples, and supporting male-only imperial succession, drawing criticism from LGBTQ+ activists.
She maintains strong ties to former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, potentially continuing his policies of military expansion and economic nationalism.
Her attendance at the Yasukuni Shrine and related statements have raised concerns in China and South Korea over historical accountability and regional tensions.

Her diplomatic outreach includes planned talks with South Korean President Lee Jae-myung and efforts to maintain stable relations with China, despite China’s concerns over Taiwan and Japan’s historical stance.
The European Union, led by Ursula von der Leyen, has expressed support, highlighting the importance of Japan-EU cooperation in global economic and security affairs.

articles.title: Los Angeles Angels Hire Kurt Suzuki as New Manager
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Los Angeles Angels have hired former catcher Kurt Suzuki as their new manager, marking the fifth full-time manager in the team’s past eight seasons. Suzuki, a 42-year-old former MLB player who won a World Series with Washington in 2019 and played his final seasons in Anaheim, joins the team after serving as a special assistant to general manager Perry Minasian. The move follows the collapse of talks with longtime favorite Albert Pujols and the departure of Ron Washington after two losing seasons. The Angels, currently in the midst of a public trial over the wrongful death of pitcher Tyler Skaggs, are facing a decade-long struggle with performance, having posted a 72-90 record in 2024 and finishing 13th in the AL. Suzuki, a fourth-generation Japanese-American and first Hawaiian-born full-time MLB manager, brings both experience and cultural significance to the role, while the team continues its long-standing challenge of breaking through a 10-year losing streak and playoff drought.
keyTakeAways: Kurt Suzuki has been hired as the new manager of the Los Angeles Angels, marking the team's fifth full-time manager in the past eight seasons.
Suzuki, a former MLB catcher with a World Series championship in 2019, joins the Angels after serving as a special assistant to general manager Perry Minasian.
The Angels have experienced a prolonged period of futility, including 10 straight losing seasons and 11 consecutive non-playoff seasons.
The hiring reflects a shift from earlier candidate Albert Pujols, whose personal services contract with the team ended and whose talks for the role collapsed.
Suzuki is the first Hawaiian-born full-time manager in MLB history and the first of his ethnic heritage (fourth-generation Japanese-American) to hold the role in the major leagues.
The Angels are currently under public scrutiny due to a wrongful death lawsuit involving pitcher Tyler Skaggs, which adds context to the team's current negative public profile.
The team’s young core, including Mike Trout, Zach Neto, and Jo Adell, has not yet shown signs of breaking through the long-standing performance slump.
